text: Greetings everyone.  I'm Doug Frey ,and I have recently been using Julia in my teaching and research here at UMBC.  I am especially interested in the Physics Informed  Neural Networks (PINNs) method and related areas.

elements.text: Greetings everyone.  I'm Doug Frey ,and I have recently been using Julia in my teaching and research here at UMBC.  I am especially interested in the Physics Informed  Neural Networks (PINNs) method and related areas.

text: Hey Doug! Check out the <#CN04R7WKE|sciml> channel for the PINNs and <#C7T968HRU|diffeq-bridged> for the other differential equation stuff.

elements.text: for the other differential equation stuff.

text: I have some students looking into new PINN training methods you might be interested in.

elements.text: I have some students looking into new PINN training methods you might be interested in.

text: Hi again Chris.  I accidently sent the previous message before it was finished.  First, thanks for all the great YouTube videos you have created.  They are a gold mine of information!    Also, I am working with the Process Engineering group at AstraZeneca (in Gaithersburg, MD) and I am proposing to  them that PINNs implemented with Julia is what they need to use for some of the problems they are addressing.  I think the existence of a very supportive Julia community will be important to them when they decide what to do.  I have created an example PINNs application (in Julia) for them in the area of process scale chromatography (an area they are interested in) so they can see what PINNs can do in an area of interest to them.  Of course, I am a novice myself in this area so I can use all the help I can  get!  I would be interested in getting from you any interesting new examples of PINNs (especially how to speed up the convergence process, which can be painfully slow at times).

elements.text: Hi again Chris.  I accidently sent the previous message before it was finished.  First, thanks for all the great YouTube videos you have created.  They are a gold mine of information! text: Yeah we can take it to a private chat. There's some pretty big things we've been testing but I don't have the student-power to publish it all right now so I'm looking for collaborators and applications to showcase. This sounds like it could be a good case.

text: Great.  We can chat privately about this in the near future. The AstraZeneca people are interested in publishing their work on this topic so I think our interactions will  be mutually beneficial.
